section: Overview and History of Beppu Onsen
content: Beppu Onsen is located in Beppu City, Oita Prefecture, and is one of Japan's largest hot spring resorts, boasting the highest number of springs and discharge volume in Japan. It is said that approximately one-tenth of the world's hot springs are concentrated in Beppu. Its history is ancient; the early 8th-century 'Iyo Province Fudoki' records a legend of an injured deity who was healed by soaking in the hot springs. Records also show that during the Kamakura period,convalescent facilities (tōji-ba) for samurai were established, and it has been beloved by people since ancient times. Today, the eight distinct hot spring districts scattered throughout the city are collectively known as "Beppu Hatto" (Beppu Eight Hot Springs).

section: Beppu Hatto Areas (Beppu, Hamawaki, Kankaiji, Horita)
content: Beppu Hatto has different spring qualities and atmospheres in each area. Beppu Onsen spreads around JR Beppu Station; "Takegawara Onsen," founded in 1879, is its symbol, and the area features a retro streetscape. Hamawaki Onsen is the birthplace of Beppu Onsen; its name derives from hot water that once gushed from the beach. Kankaiji Onsen is situated on a hill and offers spectacular views of Beppu Bay; it has developed around large resort hotels such as Suginoi Hotel. Horita Onsen is a quiet mountain hot spring that flourished as a tōji-ba since the Edo period.

section: Beppu Hatto Areas (Myoban, Kannawa, Shibaseki, Kamegawa)
content: Myoban Onsen is an area with a sulfurous aroma where traditional "yunohana" (hot spring mineral deposits) cultivation is practiced, and you can enjoy the unique scenery of thatched-roof huts lining the streets. Kannawa Onsen is the area with the most steam rising in Beppu; the tōji culture remains strong, and "jigoku-mushi" (hell cooking)—steaming vegetables and seafood at once using hot spring steam—is famous. Shibaseki Onsen is in a quiet environment where you can also enjoy forest bathing, and is known for its highly therapeutic springs. Kamegawa Onsen is a coastal area; it was where Edo-period travelers rested their weary bodies, and the "Kaibin Sunayu" (seaside sand bath) where hot springs well up from the sand is famous.

The classic Beppu sightseeing experience is the "Beppu Jigoku Meguri" (Beppu Hell Tour), which visits all seven unique natural hot spring sources including Umi Jigoku (cobalt blue pool), Chinoike Jigoku (Japan's oldest natural hell with distinctive bright red mud), and Tatsumaki Jigoku (geyser). A combined admission ticket is 2,400 yen for adults and 1,200 yen for children; hours are 8:00 to 17:00, open year-round. Beppu Ropeway takes about 10 minutes to reach the summit of Mt. Tsurumi at 1,375m elevation, offering panoramic views of Beppu Bay and the city. Beppu Tower is Japan's third-oldest radio tower and is designated as a National Registered Tangible Cultural Property. Hyotan Onsen is a historic day-trip hot spring facility in the Kannawa area, with sand baths and waterfall baths being particularly popular. Jojima Highland Park features Japan's first wooden coaster "Jupiter" and is popular with families.

The Beppu Hell Tour consists of seven hells. Umi Jigoku was formed by an eruption of Mt. Tsurumi approximately 1,200 years ago; its 98°C cobalt blue pool presents a mystical sight. Chinoike Jigoku, recorded as "Aka-yu-sen" in the Bungo Fudoki, is Japan's oldest natural hell, characterized by bright red mud. The red clay produced here is used to make "Chinoike Nanko" (Chinoike Ointment), effective for skin diseases. Oniishibozu Jigoku gets its name from gray hot mud boiling in spherical shapes resembling a monk's head. Oniyama Jigoku is also called "Wani Jigoku" (Crocodile Hell); in 1923 it became the first place in Japan to use hot spring heat for crocodile breeding, and now keeps about 70 crocodiles. Tatsumaki Jigoku is a geyser that erupts hot water and steam at regular intervals. Shiraike Jigoku is colorless and transparent when erupting but turns bluish-white as temperature and pressure drop; the garden keeps large tropical fish. Umi Jigoku, Chinoike Jigoku, Tatsumaki Jigoku, and Shiraike Jigoku are designated as National Scenic Beauties.

Beppu has many unique local dishes. Jigoku-mushi cuisine is a healthy cooking method that uses hot spring steam (around 100°C) to steam vegetables and seafood at once; you can experience it at places like "Jigoku Mushi Kobo Kannawa" in the Kannawa area. Tori-ten is a dish that originated in Beppu—chicken coated in batter and fried as tempura, typically eaten with ponzu and mustard. Beppu reimen is a unique adaptation of noodle culture brought from former Manchuria, featuring firm noodles and Japanese-style broth soup. Seki aji and Seki saba are premium brand fish caught by rod in the Bungo Channel. Dango-jiru and yaseuma are Oita local dishes using flat wheat noodles.

Beppu Onsen is accessible by multiple means of transportation. By train, it takes about 2 hours from Hakata Station on the JR Limited Express "Sonic." By airplane, the "Airport Express Bus (Air Liner)" from Oita Airport takes about 45 to 50 minutes. Ferries operate from Osaka via MOL Ferry Sunflower and from Ehime via Uwajima Unyu Ferry. By car, "Beppu IC" on the Oita Expressway is the nearest interchange. Buses are convenient for getting around Beppu City; for the Hell Tour, take bus No. 2, 5, or 24 from Beppu Station West Exit and get off at "Kannawa" or "Umi Jigoku-mae."

section: Diversity of Beppu Onsen Spring Quality
content: Beppu Onsen's greatest feature is its diversity of spring quality; of the 11 types of hot spring water that exist in Japan, 10 types are found within Beppu City. Each area of Beppu Hatto has different spring qualities: Beppu Onsen and Hamawaki Onsen have many simple hot springs and bicarbonate springs that are gentle on the skin. Kannawa Onsen is mainly sodium chloride springs with high heat-retention effects; Myoban Onsen has sulfur and acidic springs with antibacterial effects and efficacy for chronic skin conditions. Kankaiji Onsen has chloride springs with high moisturizing effects; Kamegawa Onsen has sodium chloride springs also used for sand baths. Being able to enjoy such varied spring qualities within a single city is one reason Beppu Onsen is called "Japan's No. 1 Hot Spring City."

section: Recommended Ways to Enjoy Beppu Onsen
content: Recommended ways to enjoy Beppu Onsen include first touring all seven hells on the "Beppu Jigoku Meguri," from the cobalt blue Umi Jigoku to the bright red Chinoike Jigoku. In the Kannawa area, you can experience jigoku-mushi cuisine at "Jigoku Mushi Kobo Kannawa," enjoying healthy meals of steamed vegetables and seafood. At "Kaibin Sunayu" in Kamegawa Onsen, you can experience a sand bath in hot springs welling up from the sand—a popular bathing method unique to Beppu. Hyotan Onsen offers diverse baths including sand baths and waterfall baths all in one place. In Myoban Onsen, the scenery of yunohana cultivation with thatched-roof huts is also a highlight. Beppu's greatest appeal is being able to enjoy various spring qualities and atmospheres in one city by touring Beppu Hatto.

section: Beppu Onsen Efficacy and Recommended For
content: Beppu Onsen has 10 of Japan's 11 types of spring quality, and its greatest appeal is being able to choose the optimal hot spring for your symptoms and goals. Beppu and Hamawaki's simple hot springs and bicarbonate springs are mild and gentle on the skin, especially recommended for hot spring beginners, children, seniors, and those with sensitive skin. Kannawa's sodium chloride springs have high heat-retention effects and suit those suffering from cold sensitivity or wanting to warm up from the core in winter. Myoban's sulfur and acidic springs have strong antibacterial power and are recommended for those with chronic skin conditions, atopic dermatitis, or skin issues like acne and athlete's foot. Kankaiji's chloride springs excel in moisturizing effects and suit those with dry skin or seeking beautiful skin. Kamegawa's sand bath covers the whole body in sand for high perspiration effects, popular with those interested in detox or diet, or wanting to boost metabolism from lack of exercise. Beppu is ideal for those wanting long-term tōji stays or hot spring enthusiasts who want to try various springs, as you can tour diverse spring qualities in one city.
